greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Table T(n,k) giving number of ways of obtaining exactly 0 correct answers on an (n,k)-matching problem (1 <= k <= n).
comment: Hanson et al. define the (n,k)-matching problem in the following realistic way. A matching question on an exam has k questions with n possible answers to choose from, each question having a unique answer. If a student guesses the answers at random, using each answer at most once, what is the probability of obtaining r of the k correct answers?
The T(n,k) represent the number of ways of obtaining exactly zero correct answers, i.e., r=0, given k questions and n possible answers, 1 <= k <= n.
T(n,k) is the number of injections from [1,...,k] into [1,...,n] with no fixed points. - _David Bevan_, Apr 29 2013
link: D. Hanson, K. Seyffarth and J. H. Weston, Matchings, Derangements, Rencontres, Mathematics Magazine, Vol. 56, No. 4, September 1983.
StackExchange, How many injective functions f:[1,...,m]->[1,...,n] have no fixed point?
formula: T(n,k) = F(n,k)*Sum{((-1)^j)*C(k, j)*(n-j)! (j=0 to k)}, where F(n,k) = 1/(n-k)! for 1 <= k <= n.
T(n,k) = (n-1)*T(n-1,k-1) + (k-1)*T(n-2,k-2) with T(n,1) = (n-1) and T(n,n) = A000166(n) [Hanson et al.]

T(n,k) = k!(n-k)![z^n*u^k]J(z,u) where J(z,u) = exp(z(1-u+z*u^2)/(1-z*u))/(1-z*u) is the exponential generating function of labeled digraphs consisting just of directed paths and oriented cycles (of length at least 2), z marking the vertices and u the edges; [z^n*u^k]J(z,u) is the coefficient of z^n*u^k in J(z,u). - _David Bevan_, Apr 29 2013
example: Formatted as a triangular array (mirror image of A086764):
maple: A076731 := proc(n,k): (1/(n-k)!)*A061312(n-1,k-1) end: A061312:=proc(n,k): add(((-1)^j)*binomial(k+1,j)*(n+1-j)!, j=0..k+1) end: for n from 1 to 7 do seq(A076731(n,k), k=1..n) od; seq(seq(A076731(n,k), k=1..n), n=1..9); # _Johannes W. Meijer_, Jul 27 2011
mathematica: t[n_,k_] := k!(n - k)! SeriesCoefficient[Exp[z(1-u+u^2z)/(1-z u)]/(1-z u), {z,0,n}, {u,0,k}]; Table[t[n,k], {n,9}, {k,n}] //TableForm (* _David Bevan_, Apr 29 2013 *)
t[n_, k_] := Pochhammer[n-k+1, k]*Hypergeometric1F1[-k, -n, -1]; Table[t[n, k], {n, 1, 10}, {k, 1, n}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Nov 29 2013 *)
results.author: _Mohammad K. Azarian_, Oct 28 2002
